chapter.htmlHeader: How should I diagnose neonatal jaundice?
chapter.htmlStringContent:
• Base the diagnosis of neonatal jaundice on clinical observation at every contact, particularly within the first 72 hours.
    • If the baby has one or more risk factors for developing significant hyperbilirubinaemia, ensure they are re-examined during the first 48 hours.
    • Record findings in the notes.
  • Examine the baby in bright, preferably natural light, for example in daylight by a window.
    • Look at the skin of the whole body, and blanch to assess for jaundice (for example gently pressing on the nose).
    • Also examine the sclerae, gums, and palate.
  • If there is doubt about the diagnosis, consider referral to a neonatologist or paediatrician (depending on local availability) for further assessment.
  • Offer parents and carers information on:
    • How to check the baby for jaundice.
    • What to do if they suspect jaundice.
    • The importance of seeking urgent medical attention if jaundice is suspected within the first 24 hours.
    • Observing for signs of adequate hydration.
    • The importance of checking the baby's nappies for dark urine or pale stools.

chapters.fullItemName: Have I got the right topic?

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
The recommendations on diagnosis of neonatal jaundice are largely based on expert opinion in the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence guideline Jaundice in newborn babies under 28 days [NICE, 2016] and are also consistent with the recommendations within the Queensland Maternity and Neonatal Clinical Guideline Neonatal jaundice [Queensland Health, 2019].

Recording examination findings

  • A previous expert reviewer of this CKS topic emphasized the importance of specifically recording the presence or absence of jaundice when a neonate is seen.

Referral

  • Experts acknowledge that it can be difficult to detect jaundice, particularly in babies with darker skin [NICE, 2016; Queensland Health, 2019]. CKS has therefore pragmatically recommended referral of babies for whom the diagnosis of jaundice is uncertain. This is based on the limited resources available in primary care to measure bilirubin levels and the potentially serious implications of a missed diagnosis of neonatal jaundice.

Information for parents and carers

  • Jaundice occurring within the first 24 hours is a risk factor for severe hyperbilirubinaemia and/or jaundice caused by haemolysis or underlying disease. Dehydration/poor feeding are also risk factors for severe hyperbilirubinaemia, and pale stools and dark urine indicate underlying liver disease. Parents/carers should be provided with this information as early identification and the seeking of urgent medical advice are important to allow appropriate investigations and treatment to avoid serious sequelae [NICE, 2016].
